problem:
If $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = -8,$ then find
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix}.\]
solution:
Since $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = -8,$ $ad - bc = -8.$  Then
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix} = bc - ad = \boxed{8}.\](Why does this make sense geometrically?)
model_solution:
## Step 1: We need to find the determinant of the second matrix using the given determinant of the first matrix.
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix} = bd - ad\]

## Step 2:  The determinant of the second matrix can be expressed in terms of the determinant of the first matrix.
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix} = -(ad - bd)\]

## Step 3:  Simplify the expression for the determinant of the second matrix.
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix} = -(ad - bd) = -(-8)\]

## Step 4: Simplify the expression further.
\[\begin{vmatrix} b & a \\ d & c \end{vmatrix} = 8\]

The final answer is: $\boxed{8}$
